summary:
"Fantasia" is a classic 1940 Disney movie that combines animation with famous classical music. Conducted by Leopold Stokowski, the film features eight different segments, with music critic Deems Taylor introducing each one. Originally planned as a short film, "The Sorcerer's Apprentice," it evolved into a feature-length production due to its high production values.

The film was groundbreaking for its use of stereo sound, called Fantasound, making it the first commercial film with this technology. Despite critical acclaim, it didn't make a profit initially due to World War II and high costs. Over time, "Fantasia" has gained a reputation as one of the greatest animated films, with a sequel, "Fantasia 2000," released in 1999.
title: Fantasia (1940 film)
